body_html:
@vincentvanhoucke Interesting... I checked again and I agree with you that as long as text = text.decode() is ran in py3 after text is read from the file, then the rest of the code runs smoothly (because zipfile.Zipfile.read returns bytes not a string).

When I ran it last time, somehow this didn't work. So tried to keep text as bytes throughout, which led to the unreadable code~
body_text:
@vincentvanhoucke Interesting... I checked again and I agree with you that as long as text = text.decode() is ran in py3 after text is read from the file, then the rest of the code runs smoothly (because zipfile.Zipfile.read returns bytes not a string).
When I ran it last time, somehow this didn't work. So tried to keep text as bytes throughout, which led to the unreadable code~
body:
@vincentvanhoucke Interesting... I checked again and I agree with you that as long as `text = text.decode()` is ran in py3 after `text` is read from the file, then the rest of the code runs smoothly (because `zipfile.Zipfile.read` returns `bytes` not a string). 

When I ran it last time, somehow this didn't work. So tried to keep `text` as `bytes` throughout, which led to the unreadable code~
